message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote: draft Translator's Preface now or after?">
The author asks: should the translator write a draft of the Translator's Preface NOW (before full translation begins) to capture all the decisions while they're fresh — with the understanding it will be revised after translation is complete? Or should we wait until after?

Reply "NOW" or "AFTER" with a brief reason.
</teammate-message>

input.content: NOW — The Translator's Preface is not just a paratext; it functions as a specification document. Writing it now forces the translator to articulate the translation principles (Jing transliteration, -scape system, register strategy, glossary rationale, the performative dimension) in prose form before applying them, which will surface any remaining inconsistencies or gaps in our framework. This is the same logic as writing tests before code. The draft will inevitably be revised after translation — tone, emphasis, and examples will shift once the translator has lived inside all eight essays in English — but the core decisions (all seven resolved Q-files, the Dictionary, the structural principles) are settled and at risk of being forgotten or muddled if not written down now while the full expert consultation is fresh in context. Wittgenstein's own method is relevant here: articulating a position is itself a form of clarification. The act of writing the preface now will clarify the translation approach for the translator themselves.
input.summary: Vote NOW: captures decisions, surfaces gaps, clarifies approach

routing.summary: Vote NOW: captures decisions, surfaces gaps, clarifies approach

content.text: Vote submitted. Awaiting next instructions from the team lead.
